--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, ibrahim demir <ibrahimdemire@...> wrote:

> I=
 have a question about running junit tests with a build tool. Some
people s=
ay maven is the best choise to use with junit and some say ant
is the best =
for that. But I there is no real metric about the performance.
> 
> So what=
 is your choice about the build tools. I will be very pleased
if you share =
your expreince about the test run time,perfomance,plugins
etc..

We have be=
en using maven and since 6 months maven2 in our project
(which uses multipl=
e sub-projects). I like the IDE integration and it
works well with our cont=
inuous build system (Luntbuild and currently
as trial TeamCity). I think pe=
rformance depends more on other factors.
One developer on our team was comp=
laining about the build time with
all tests, which on his machine took more=
 than 10 minutes (and because
of that he didn't run them often enough). On =
my machine (different OS,
different hardware) I got it down to 2-3 minutes.=
 In order to solve
his long build time, we are trying out TeamCity now, so =
that a
developer can run the tests on the build server before checking in h=
is
code. The build server can scaled and optimized.

Maven has a learning c=
urve as all tools but until now we are pleased
with it. I does what it shou=
ld be doing. I recently mavenized 3 old
legacy projects and it was nice to =
see how it simplified things, which
should save time and money.

Regards,

=
Harald
